title: Black Caucus: Racism
creator: The Occidental
description: Occidental weekly letter to the editor submitted by the Black Students' Caucus that appears to be in response to the Kerner Commission (then known as the National Advisory Commision on Civil Disorders) stating the student groups stance on anti-Black racism in America. The article focuses on the concept of Black Power, everyday racism that Black people in America are subjected to, as well as the historic legacy and current responsibility that white people have to address these tensions.
subject: universities; civil rights movement; college activism; Black student associations; race in America; Kerner Commission
source: Special Collections and College Archives, Occidental College, Los Angeles, CA.
rights: Property and literary rights reside with the Occidental College Library. For permission to reproduce or publish, please contact Special Collections.
image_alt_text: Occidental letter to the editor from the BSC in response to the recent Kerner Commission Report about race relations in America.

title: The 'Black-white confrontation' Sunday Forum
description: On January 21st 1968, Occidental students, staff, and administrators gathered in Herrick Hall to discuss race relations on campus, in Eagle Rock, and the greater United States. Student perceptions and reactions are captured in Occidental Weekly articles and letters to the editor.
subject: universities; civil rights movement; college activism; Black student associations; race in America
rights: Property and literary rights reside with the Occidental College Library. For permission to reproduce or publish, please contact Special Collections.
image_alt_text: Photo of student panelists for Black-white confrontation sunday forum

title: Sunday forum: black and white in confrontation
creator: The Occidental
description: Occidental weekly article about the upcoming Sunday forum about race relations on Occidental's campus. Topics of discussion include: the College's admissions policy, the fate of the BSC, the question of a race problem on campus, and the microcosm of Occidental within the greater Civil Rights movement
subject: universities; civil rights movement; college activism; Black student associations; race in America
source: Special Collections and College Archives, Occidental College, Los Angeles, CA.
rights: Property and literary rights reside with the Occidental College Library. For permission to reproduce or publish, please contact Special Collections.
image_alt_text: Occidental student newpaper article about the upcoming Sunday forum about race relations on campus. There is an image in the center left of the article of a student Joe or José Colon, he is looking away from the camera with a stern gaze.

title: 300 see black-white confrontation
creator: The Occidental
description: Occidental weekly article detailing the black-white confrontation Sunday forum that occured the week prior. Remarks from students and adminstrators are quoted in the article. The page also includes a section of another article about current in new members of various Greek life organizations.
subject: universities; civil rights movement; college activism; Black student associations; race in America
source: Special Collections and College Archives, Occidental College, Los Angeles, CA.
rights: Property and literary rights reside with the Occidental College Library. For permission to reproduce or publish, please contact Special Collections.
image_alt_text: Occidental student newspaper article reporting the events of the Sunday forum on campus race relations. There is an additional unrelated article about Greek life.

title: Black like everybody
creator: The Occidental
description: Occidental weekly letter to the editor written by Don Cornwell, ASOC Vice President. Cornwell describes his frustrations with reactions to the Black-white confrontation Sunday forum. Cornwell crticizes the expectation that problems needto be tangible when the racial conflict stems from perception and treament of black students on campus and greater society.
subject: universities; civil rights movement; college activism; Black student associations; race in America
source: Special Collections and College Archives, Occidental College, Los Angeles, CA.
rights: Property and literary rights reside with the Occidental College Library. For permission to reproduce or publish, please contact Special Collections.
image_alt_text: Occidental letter to the editor from current ASOC Vice President, Don Cornwell, expressing opinions on the response to the black-white confrontation Sunday forum.

title: Black Arts Week Imminent

title: George Ellison Jr, the first Black man enrolled at Occidental College
creator: Occidental College Special Collections and College Archives
description: George Ellison started courses at Occidental in the fall of 1947 as a part of the Telluride Association's partnership with Occidental College, which allowed students in their work and education program to attend courses on campus. Ellison decided to enroll in The College after finishing the Quaker affiliated program and graduated with a degree in psychology in 1952.
subject: universities; Black history; stafford ellison wright endowment
source: " from 'Platinum Jubilee' in Occidental Magazine's summer 2022 issue
rights: Property and literary rights reside with the Occidental College Library. For permission to reproduce or publish, please contact Special Collections.
image_alt_text: Sepia toned photo of George Ellison Jr smiling at the camers

title: Janet Stafford, the first Black woman enrolled at Occidental
creator: Occidental College Special Collections and College Archives
description: Janet Stafford was the first Black woman to enroll at Occidental College. Her education in part was funded by the efforts of the Eagle Rock Council for Civic Unity. To fundraise, they booked Langston Hughes to speak at Thorne Hall on March 1948. However, the event was moved to Scott United Methodist Church after Oxy's Board of Trustees cancelled the rental due to Hughes' communist ideals and the fear mongering of McCarthyism.
subject: universities; Black history; stafford ellison wright endowment
source: " from 'Platinum Jubilee' in Occidental Magazine's summer 2022 issue
rights: Property and literary rights reside with the Occidental College Library. For permission to reproduce or publish, please contact Special Collections.
